title: Jumping into the Jade Forest in Mists of Pandaria
description: I have some vague memories of starting off in Mists of Pandaria back in the day.  They primarily involve parachuting off the alliance sky battleship thingy and into the expansion. Even as I was getting to that on the first evening it had already been announced that somebody had achieved the world first to level […]
author: Wilhelm Arcturus
excerpt: I have some vague memories of starting off in Mists of Pandaria back in the day. They primarily involve parachuting off the alliance sky battleship thingy and into the expansion. Even as I was get…
text: I have some vague memories of starting off in Mists of Pandaria back in the day.  They primarily involve parachuting off the alliance sky battleship thingy and into the expansion. Jumping into Pandaria Even as I was getting to that on the first evening it had already been announced that somebody had achieved the world first to level 90 for the expansion… though that was later contested as a second streamer claims they got in a couple minutes ahead of the first stream who claimed the crown. Of course this was all down to people streaming for attention.  What else could you expect here in 2025? Anyway, I didn’t purposefully avoid the initial rush when the expansion opened, I was just busy with work when launch time hit.  I couldn’t slip away as I had done with past classic launches. But I was happy enough to let the first mass of players get ahead of me.  So when I showed up in Stormwind to get things going there were just a few people hanging around the NPC that sends you on your way. Rell Nightwind will send you on your way You have to get yourself to the Skyfire… the ship that took down Deathwing, as Admiral Rogers keeps telling you when you get there… for an expedition into the unknown.  You can get there because you’ve had an expansion and a half of unfettered access to flying mounts. Flying to the Skyfire That is all going to change when you arrive because Blizz in part blamed flying for people finishing then bailing on Cataclysm early.  In Pandaria you are going to be stuck to the ground for a long time.  But first you have to get there, so we get a cinematic with some exposition which I have already forgotten. We’re going to Pandaria… and we’re in mist… go figure And then you arrive and the Horde are all over and this is an expansion where we’re fighting the Horde rather than cooperating with them, and so it is attack copters launch and we’re taking hits and it is time to jump into the fray and at one point there are a bunch of Horde in the water swimming for the shore and Admiral Rogers in a rage and is telling everybody to Bismark Sea them, shoot survivors in the water, and even Rell was starting to feel uncomfortable with the turn of events when suddenly the pandas show up and point out our imbalance with nature has brought out the sha of disgruntlement and this negative emotional feedback loop is driving us into a blood lust, which isn’t a good look for a pair of empires looking to woo the pandas into a coalition with one of us against the other. And then we go hang out with the pandas, learn a bit about them, and start the great competition to recruit them to our side… or something.  I am not always in tune with the big picture.  This isn’t getting Frodo to Mordor, this is politics.  But the place is at least pretty. The menace of the Skyfire looms in the background At this point I was reminded that I don’t really like/enjoy the first quest hub in Pandaria, though it is not easy for me to articulate exactly why.  Being there and starting out definitely brought out a bit of “oh no, not this again” in me. I think it is a combo of the quests involving a fair bit of running back and forth… which among other things drives home the “no flying for you today!” point… along with the fact that the starting area was setup to handle something of a flood of players, but as soon as that flood has gone past you’re in a bit of a slog at parts where you just want to get to an objective but you have to slay a bunch of mobs just to go pick up the dingus you’ve been sent to get. Whatever it is, that first area taxes my patience with the game and I ended up taking a break now and then to swap over and work on my panda monk over in the new starter area. At least he gets transport between areas That too is a bit tedious, but a different sort of tedious I guess, because when one got on my nerves I would swap over to the other. The funny thing is that once I am past that first area in Pandaria, everything is fine.  Things settle down and I get into that happy place of doing quests and moving forward. Once I make it here I am good Meanwhile, I made it to the big choice on my panda monk. Choose your side I went Alliance because that is where our guild is.  You do have to do a bit more stuff in Stormwind to get going… while walking through as the residents try to figure out what you are. This passes for humor in Stormwind From there you are on the normal track to the level cap, starting in Westfall all the way through Outland, Northrend, and back to the old world until you’re ready for Pandaria.  I am not sure I am that committed to yet another character, but we shall see. I am, however, into the expansion.  We shall see how up for it I really am.
html:
I have some vague memories of starting off in Mists of Pandaria back in the day.  They primarily involve parachuting off the alliance sky battleship thingy and into the expansion.

Jumping into Pandaria

Even as I was getting to that on the first evening it had already been announced that somebody had achieved the world first to level 90 for the expansion… though that was later contested as a second streamer claims they got in a couple minutes ahead of the first stream who claimed the crown.

Of course this was all down to people streaming for attention.  What else could you expect here in 2025?

Anyway, I didn’t purposefully avoid the initial rush when the expansion opened, I was just busy with work when launch time hit.  I couldn’t slip away as I had done with past classic launches.

But I was happy enough to let the first mass of players get ahead of me.  So when I showed up in Stormwind to get things going there were just a few people hanging around the NPC that sends you on your way.

Rell Nightwind will send you on your way

You have to get yourself to the Skyfire… the ship that took down Deathwing, as Admiral Rogers keeps telling you when you get there… for an expedition into the unknown.  You can get there because you’ve had an expansion and a half of unfettered access to flying mounts.

Flying to the Skyfire

That is all going to change when you arrive because Blizz in part blamed flying for people finishing then bailing on Cataclysm early.  In Pandaria you are going to be stuck to the ground for a long time.  But first you have to get there, so we get a cinematic with some exposition which I have already forgotten.

We’re going to Pandaria… and we’re in mist… go figure

And then you arrive and the Horde are all over and this is an expansion where we’re fighting the Horde rather than cooperating with them, and so it is attack copters launch and we’re taking hits and it is time to jump into the fray and at one point there are a bunch of Horde in the water swimming for the shore and Admiral Rogers in a rage and is telling everybody to Bismark Sea them, shoot survivors in the water, and even Rell was starting to feel uncomfortable with the turn of events when suddenly the pandas show up and point out our imbalance with nature has brought out the sha of disgruntlement and this negative emotional feedback loop is driving us into a blood lust, which isn’t a good look for a pair of empires looking to woo the pandas into a coalition with one of us against the other.

And then we go hang out with the pandas, learn a bit about them, and start the great competition to recruit them to our side… or something.  I am not always in tune with the big picture.  This isn’t getting Frodo to Mordor, this is politics.  But the place is at least pretty.

The menace of the Skyfire looms in the background

At this point I was reminded that I don’t really like/enjoy the first quest hub in Pandaria, though it is not easy for me to articulate exactly why.  Being there and starting out definitely brought out a bit of “oh no, not this again” in me.

I think it is a combo of the quests involving a fair bit of running back and forth… which among other things drives home the “no flying for you today!” point… along with the fact that the starting area was setup to handle something of a flood of players, but as soon as that flood has gone past you’re in a bit of a slog at parts where you just want to get to an objective but you have to slay a bunch of mobs just to go pick up the dingus you’ve been sent to get.

Whatever it is, that first area taxes my patience with the game and I ended up taking a break now and then to swap over and work on my panda monk over in the new starter area.

At least he gets transport between areas

That too is a bit tedious, but a different sort of tedious I guess, because when one got on my nerves I would swap over to the other.

The funny thing is that once I am past that first area in Pandaria, everything is fine.  Things settle down and I get into that happy place of doing quests and moving forward.

Once I make it here I am good

Meanwhile, I made it to the big choice on my panda monk.

Choose your side

I went Alliance because that is where our guild is.  You do have to do a bit more stuff in Stormwind to get going… while walking through as the residents try to figure out what you are.

This passes for humor in Stormwind

From there you are on the normal track to the level cap, starting in Westfall all the way through Outland, Northrend, and back to the old world until you’re ready for Pandaria.  I am not sure I am that committed to yet another character, but we shall see.

I am, however, into the expansion.  We shall see how up for it I really am.
